instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON â€“ CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message: Hello. This board came to me about 2 months ago dead. Shorted <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. I fixed the short and the board worked for the next 1 or 2 months. Last week costumer brought it back with a strange symptom. If the machine is left off for about 10 minutes it starts one time. No matter if you leave it on for 5 seconds or 1 hour, if you shut it down it won't power again immediately. If I leave it sitting on the bench for some minutes it turns on again for one time and does the same. When it stops working I have quarter fan spin. All S0 coils pulse during the quarter fan except the CPU VCORE ones. Any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message: Does it start in SMC bypass then?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message: It doesn't

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message: Check the PCH's RTC signals at that moment.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message: While trying SMC bypass or while it does quarter fan?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.34V
<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_G3_PCH_DCPRTC</SIGNAL> - 1.552V

This while quarter fanning. I don't know if these are the voltages you asked. Correct me if I'm wrong.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message:
Sorry, if there is quarter fan spin, then RTC signals should be good.

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulsing?
Inspect <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>/03 and solders around <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message: Resistors are good. Re-flower <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> pressing it down with tweezers and touched pins with iron to make sure it's not solder problem. Same thing. First time I plug in the board it turns on. If I unplug and plug it in right after it won't turn on, just quarter fan. If I let it sitting on the bench for some minutes it'll turn on again once and do the same thing. <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulses when quarter fan.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message:
Check for corrosion near <CHIP>U5750</CHIP> and <CHIP>U5010</CHIP>.
Change <CAPACITOR>C5001</CAPACITOR>, just in case.

Same thing happens if you keep keyboard disconnected?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message: Replaced the cap, no corrosion around both chips. Same results... I'm testing the board on the bench, no peripherals attached.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message: It's not even turning on at first time anymore, just quarter fan spinning.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message:
Reball SMC.
Seems that something reacted to heat when changed <CAPACITOR>C5001</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message: Reballed. Same thing. Quarter fan, cycling.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS stable?
Still not turning on in SMC bypass?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message: Replaced SMC. Now I only get quarter fan. Machine enter S0 state, all rails present except CPU VCORE.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message:
Quarter fan spin and S0 present only that moment (I suppose)?
<RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>/03 both good?

SMC from donor board, same model?
Be sure to have good solders.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message: No! I plug in the charger, fan tries to spin but does not. S0 rails stay present until I disconnect charger. SMC from same model. <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> and 03 reading accurately.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message:
You get quarter fan spin and all voltages remain present after that (except VCORE)???
This is really strange.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message: Yes, it's REALLY weird! But that's what's happening... It dos not get even a quarter fan, just as if the fan would start but does not. Just a little "unparking"(know this word does not exist, but still...). And all rails except VCOR remain ON.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message:
Possibly PCH, or CPU issue.
Heat both with quality flux; may be just accumulated crap underneath.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message: Ok! Will do it. Any suggestions on temperature and time?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message: 180-200 degrees for 15-20s; no need to melt the balls.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message: Tried. Same thing. I noticed high consumption of current on L7510 and L7520(around 4.5 amps) when injecting 1V on those coils. If I remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR> it draws only 0.75 amps on bench PSU. Tried replacing both mosfets, still same abnormal consumption. I think there may be a short to GND before mosfets.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message: Post exact ohm resistance to ground at L7510/20.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message:
L7510:

Black Probe on GND: 0.2Ohms
Red Probe on GND: 0.3 Ohms

L7520:

Black Probe on GND: 0.3Ohms
Red Probe on GND: 0.3 Ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message: I replaced <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR> and short gone, no more abnormal current consumption but no power! Just green light, no more S0 state. Resistance to GND raised to 1.4 Ohms on both coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message:
Is your CPU i7-3xxx?
Compare readings with similar board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message: It's an Ivy Bridge i5

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message: Reading a bit lower than other similar board I have here. Now it's reading 2 Ohms and 2.3 ohms respectively, against around 3 Ohms from other board. I think CPU may be OK.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message:
Checked on other board with i5 too?

Maybe bad PCH, or CPU; which reacted after heat applied.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message: Yes, the other board is an i5 too. Both 2.5GHZ

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message: Dead CPU then?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan
threads.message: If you have time to spend and experiment, change PCH first.
